paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: Extracted genetic variant information for the TTR gene, including penetrance data.

patients.demographics: Various ages, both male and female
patients.phenotype: Peripheral sensory-motor neuropathy, dysautonomia, and cardiomyopathy

individual_records.phenotype_details: Early-onset neuropathy with sensory loss and dysautonomia.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The most frequent mutation worldwide, V30M, has either early-onset (in the endemic areas in Portugal and Brazil, mean onset age 33 years; occasionally in other areas including Italy) or late-onset.

individual_records.phenotype_details: Late-onset neuropathy with significant cardiac involvement.
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Late-onset V30M has a different clinical picture: the neuropathy affects small and large fibres since the beginning.
Given later onset and age-dependent penetrance, family history is frequently negative.

functional_data.summary: The V30M mutation destabilizes the TTR protein, leading to amyloid fibril formation.

variants.segregation_data: Segregates with disease in families, particularly in endemic regions.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on clinical and functional studies.
variants.additional_notes: The V30M variant is the most studied and has significant clinical implications.
key_quotes: The pathogenetic model of ATTRv amyloidosis indicates that amyloidogenic, usually missense, mutations destabilize the native TTR.
The disease course, lethal if left untreated after a mean of 7–10 years, is more rapid in the late-onset variety.

extraction_metadata.notes: Data was extracted thoroughly from the main text.
